G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, ���������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, because this action arises out of a residential tenancy located in Middlesex County and the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, �������������������������������������������������������������������������������� and G.L. c. 218, ����������������������������������������������������������������������������� because the Premises are located in Lowell, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in this Court�27s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 218, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������� and G.L. c. 218, �������������������������������������������������������������������� because the Premises are located in Lowell, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in this Court�27s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the owner and/or person entitled to possession, control, and receipt of rents for the Premises, and thus is a “landlord” within the meaning of Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 186.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: The presence of mold and excessive moisture constitutes a condition that violates the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.020 (requiring a dwelling to be “in good repair, clean and free from chronic dampness, mold, and other conditions which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety and well-being of an occupant”) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (requiring owners to correct violations).

105 C.M.R. 410.020.proposition: The presence of mold and excessive moisture constitutes a condition that violates the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.020 (requiring a dwelling to be “in good repair, clean and free from chronic dampness, mold, and other conditions which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety and well-being of an occupant”) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (requiring owners to correct violations).

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: The presence of mold and excessive moisture constitutes a condition that violates the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.020 (requiring a dwelling to be “in good repair, clean and free from chronic dampness, mold, and other conditions which may endanger or materially impair the health or safety and well-being of an occupant”) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (requiring owners to correct violations).

G.L. c. 111, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Defendant�27s position is that Plaintiff “caused” the mold problem and therefore Defendant has disclaimed responsibility to address the underlying cause of the mold, even though, under Massachusetts law, landlords bear responsibility for maintaining the premises in habitable condition and in compliance with the State Sanitary Code.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199	6200 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant�27s position is that Plaintiff “caused” the mold problem and therefore Defendant has disclaimed responsibility to address the underlying cause of the mold, even though, under Massachusetts law, landlords bear responsibility for maintaining the premises in habitable condition and in compliance with the State Sanitary Code.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that, under Massachusetts law, a residential lease is a contract in which the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition, in conformity with at least the State Sanitary Code, and that this duty is not excused by lack of landlord fault or by reasonable repair efforts. While the case involves heat and hot water rather than mold specifically, its reasoning is directly about the landlord’s non‑delegable, fault‑independent duty to maintain habitability, making it strong authority against a landlord’s attempt to shift responsibility to the tenant for code-related habitability defects such as mold.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” … “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\t603.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is guaranteed by statute, G.L. c. 186, ����������������������������������������������������������������� and prohibits a landlord from directly or indirectly interfering with a tenant�27s quiet enjoyment by acts or omissions that substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\t603.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 as the statutory “quiet enjoyment” provision and explains that it covers a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” of residential premises. It further states that, by using the phrase “quiet enjoyment,” the Legislature incorporated the common-law meaning: freedom from serious interferences that “impair the character and value of the leased premises.” Thus the case supports both that the covenant is guaranteed by statute and that it prohibits substantial interferences by a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\t603.relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774	675 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, ����������������������������������������������������������������� protects tenants from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises and is violated by conditions that create serious health and safety hazards not timely or properly corrected by the landlord after notice.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve a covenant of quiet enjoyment claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the facts describe severe conditions (heat, vermin, other defects) persisting despite notice, but the court does not analyze or articulate the elements or scope of the covenant in this decision. The discussion and holding are focused on the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy, and the covenant claim is mentioned only to note that the judge found a breach but awarded no separate damages. Thus, it does not serve as authority for the stated proposition about what violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “The judge also awarded Wideman the equivalent of two months’ rent on her retaliation claim under G. L. c. 186, § 18. No issue is raised as to these damages on appeal. Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The statute applies not only to affirmative acts of harassment or self-help, but also to significant omissions and failures to act where the landlord, with notice, allows serious defective conditions and sanitary code violations to persist.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets the quiet enjoyment statute to reach not only affirmative landlord misconduct but also significant omissions where the landlord, with notice, allows serious harmful conditions to persist. The court states that liability can arise from what the landlord “failed to do,” and explains that if the authority “failed to take any action” to remove known unlawful activity that seriously interferes with tenancies, it may have breached the covenant. This directly supports the proposition that the statute covers substantial failures to act, not just affirmative acts of harassment or self‑help.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The statute applies not only to affirmative acts of harassment or self-help, but also to significant omissions and failures to act where the landlord, with notice, allows serious defective conditions and sanitary code violations to persist.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to impose liability where the landlord “willfully or intentionally fails to furnish…heat” and treats the landlords’ failure to provide heat—despite their claimed inability to pay for oil—as actionable under the quiet enjoyment prong. While the facts involve a specific statutory duty to provide heat rather than a broad range of sanitary defects, the opinion makes clear that a landlord’s omission (failure to act to provide heat) can violate § 14 without proof of intent, fitting the proposition that the statute reaches significant failures to act, not only overt harassment or self-help. The support is somewhat indirect because the opinion focuses on heat and not a wide spectrum of sanitary code violations.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14…who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish…heat…or…who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises… The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense… A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”}

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199	601 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The existence of unsanitary, hazardous conditions that materially impair the health or safety of the tenant, including chronic dampness and mold, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, particularly where the landlord has notice and fails to cure.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) focuses on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It discusses unsanitary and hazardous conditions as Sanitary Code violations that may reduce rent liability, but does not analyze or hold that such conditions constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The tenants defend principally on the following grounds…that the Housing Inspection Department had inspected defendant’s apartment…and found said apartment to be in violation of the State Sanitary Code…that said violations and conditions…render the apartment uninhabitable… The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally… and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations….”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789	690 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord�27s failure to correct State Sanitary Code violations after notice is evidence of a substantial interference with the tenant�27s use and enjoyment and supports a claim under G.L. c. 186, �����������������������������������������������������������������.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to repair serious State Sanitary Code and related defects after notice, where it is foreseeable that this will substantially impair the value of the premises, constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). The opinion expressly ties Cruz Management’s notice of numerous sanitary, building, and fire code violations and its failure adequately to correct them to a substantial impairment of the value of the dwelling and finds a § 14 violation on that basis. This directly supports using uncorrected sanitary code violations after notice as evidence of substantial interference under c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976, 977	678 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.proposition: A landlord�27s failure to correct State Sanitary Code violations after notice is evidence of a substantial interference with the tenant�27s use and enjoyment and supports a claim under G.L. c. 186, �����������������������������������������������������������������.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.support_reasoning: The opinion involves a claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment) and discusses numerous State Sanitary Code violations and the landlord’s failure to repair, but it does not expressly tie "failure after notice" to the legal standard for substantial interference under § 14. The quoted portion focuses on rent abatement, c. 93A liability, and treble damages, and only mentions § 14 in passing without articulating the specific principle that post‑notice failure to correct code violations is evidence of substantial interference. Thus, while factually consistent, the case is not clear authority for the precise proposition stated.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976,.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that at the inception of LeClair’s tenancy there were a number of violations of the State Sanitary Code and that these problems had caused the prior tenant to vacate the premises after living there a few months. He also found that the landlord was repeatedly notified of the ongoing leaks and other problems on several occasions, and that, despite these complaints, the leakage and the roach problem remained uncorrected through April, 1982. LeClair testified that he complained about leaks "throughout the tenancy" or "through . . . fall ’81."

G.L. c. 111, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., adopted under G.L. c. 111, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������ requires that landlords maintain residential premises free from chronic dampness, mold, and other conditions that may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants.
